section.title: Creating Flows
section.para: In GÃªBR a Flow is a sequence of operations defined by you. These operations, also called the Flow's programs, are organized into the following categories according to their purpose:

listitem.para: Gain, NMO, Stack and Standard Processes

section.para: To create a Flow you must select and order programs from the above categories. Let us see how this is done:

step.para: In the tab Projects and Lines, check that you have selected My First Line, the Line you created before.

Now click on the tab Flows, then left-click on
.

The dialog box Flow "New Flow" Properties will appear, fill in a title for this Flow (for example, My First Flow). You can also give a brief description of the Flow, the author and an e-mail for contact. If you are done filling in this Flows properties click on OK.
Now select the tab Flow Editor. On the right side it will be shown a list with several menus. Choose one of them and include it in your flow with a double-click.
If you need a specific order to the selected programs of your flow, you just need to drag and drop the desired programs.

mediaobject.caption: In the Flow editor, on the right side of the main window you will see the Menus box. From this box you can add programs to your Flow, which will appear in the Flow sequence box on the left side of the main window.

step.para:
To enable a program of your flow, you will have to right-click over it and select the Configured option. The icon will change from
to

mediaobject.caption: To enable a program, select the Configured option.

tip.para:
If you want to change all programs, or a few, to the configured state simultaneously, select them by using
Ctrl Click . Then right-click on one of the selected programs, choose the option Configured from the menu that appeared. All the programs that were selected will be altered to the state

important.para:
To run a Flow all the programs listed in the Flow sequence box must be Configured (
). Otherwise the Flow will not be executed as expected.

The state of a Flow, or a set of Flows, can be changed by using the hotkey spacebar, which alters the state of the selected programs in the order Not configured, Disabled and Configured. The meaning of these states will be further described later on.

There is no limit on the number of Flows you can have in one Line.

After you have created a Flow it will be visible on the left side of the main window when the Flows tab is selected. The Details box, found on the right side of the main window, shows information on the selected Flow .

tip.para: You can alter the position of the Flow in the list by dragging the Flow with the mouse to the desired position.
Observe that the information bar just bellow the menu Actions shows the complete Flow tree of the selected Flow.

section.para:
The clipboard provides the popular set of tools known as copying and pasting. In GÃªBR a Flow (or set of Flows) can be copied to the clipboard by using the button
or by using the known shortcut
Ctrl C .

tip.para:
You can select several Flows and then copy all of them to the clipboard by holding
Ctrl Left-click or
Shift Left-click .

section.title: Pasting Flows from the clipboard
section.para:
After copying , a Flow (or a set of Flows) you can paste it by clicking on the button
or by simply using the shortcut
Ctrl V .

tip.para: Any Flow (or a set of Flows) that has been copied to the clipboard can be pasted to any Line. Simply switch to the Projects and Lines tab, select the desired Line, then go back to the Flows tab and paste the Flow(s).

section.title: Saving a Flow's state
section.para: Working with GÃªBR you will find situations where it will be useful to use an existing Flow as a basis to create new Flows. For example, you might want to experiment with Flows that are only slightly different from one another, however without having to discard or modify the original Flow.

One way of doing this is to copy and paste the Flow (see the section and ). Another way is to save the state of the original Flow, then edit it to your heart desire, and when you wish you can return the Flow to its original state. To save the Flow's state:

step.para:
Select the Flow and left-click on
.
If you want, you can write a comment on the state in the dialog box Save the Flow's state, as to identify this saved state later on.

note.para: There is no limit on the number of states for each Flow.

section.para:
To open the list of saved states left-click on
, to the right of the button
, then select the state you wish to recover. Whenever you select a saved state from the list, the dialog Backup Current State will appear. If you click on Yes the dialog Save the Flow's State will appear, where you can save this new state. If you click on No, GÃªBR will simply revert to the chosen state without saving the current state.

tip.para: If you are sure you have saved your current state, we recommend that you click on No, in the dialog box Backup Current State, as to avoid a bloated state list.

caution.para: GÃªBR continuously saves the list of Flow states. Even if you turn off your computer this list will be recovered when you open GÃªBR again. However, if you delete the Flow all the saved states will immediately disappear forever.

section.title: Importing a Flow
section.para: GÃªBR allows you to import Flows that were previously exported . To do so:

step.para: Check that you have already created and selected a Line, in the tab Projects and Lines. Remember that Flows can only exist inside Lines (see this concept in Section ). To import a Flow you must first select a Line (or , if one does not exist).

Select the tab Flows and left-click on
.
Navigate through the Choose a Flow to import and select a Flow you wish to import (only the file types flw will appear).

section.para: The imported Flow will be listed along with any other Flows of the selected Line.

section.title: Exporting a Flow
section.para: Although GÃªBR maintains all your data, you still might wish to copy your Flows to file (perhaps to share with others or as a backup). To export a Flow:

step.para: Select the Flow you wish to save.
In the window Save Flow, navigate to the directory you desire and type a name for the file (GÃªBR will automatically determine the extension flw).

section.title: Executing a Flow
section.para:
This command is present in the tab Flows and in the tab Flow editor through the button
.
In the tab Flows you are able to execute several Flows sequentially by first: selecting the Flows you wish to use, and then left-click on
.
section.tip: You can select several Flows and execute them sequentially by pressing Ctrl+R.
You can select several Flows and execute them parallelly by pressing Ctrl+Shift+R.
section.caution: When executing multiple flows, the configuration of the first flow (when and where to execute) is going to be replicated to the other flows.

section.title: Editing comments
section.para: This button appears in the Projects and Lines tab and in Flows tab. This button allows the user to add comments about the selected Line or Flow. See .

section.title: View Report
section.para: This button appears in the Projects and Lines tab and in Flows tab. This button allows the user to View the report about the Line or Flow in use. The difference is that the Line's report can include the Flow's report. All other functions are described in .
